As a consultant I get to see a lot of code bases and on Android, by far, the most common anti-pattern that I see is what I would call the BaseClass anti-pattern.

In this article I will explain what it is, why it is bad and why it is so seductive.

What is it?

So what is the BaseClass anti-pattern and how do I detect it?

  1. Start out by opening the android project.
  2. Locate a activity or fragment class in said project.
  3. Does it extend something called BaseActivity or BaseFragment.

If the answer #3 is yes then you my friend has falled victim to the BaseClass anti-pattern. If you open the BaseActivity or the BaseFragment class and that class contains more than 50 lines of code then you are in deep trouble.

So why is this bad?

I will answer why it is bad by asking a question. What is the responsibility of the BaseActivity? Except for being an Activity what does the class name tell you? Nothing right...

So the naming is bad, so lets give it a better name. Well if you open the class chances are that you will find something code like this:

class BaseActivity extends AppCompatActivity {
  void onCreate() {
    super.onCreate();
  }
}
